Current Policies: Abortion is completely banned with very limited exceptions | State constitution explicitly excludes abortion rights | Patients forced to wait 48 hours after counseling (not required to be in-person) to obtain an abortion | State Medicaid coverage of abortion care is banned except in very limited circumstances | Medication abortion must be provided in person because state bans the use of telehealth or mailing pills or requires in-person visit | Parental consent or notice is required for a minor's abortion | Only physicians can provide abortions and not other qualified health care professionals | Unnecessary regulations are in force and designed to shutter abortion clinics without basis in medical standards
Only physicians can provide abortions and not other qualified health care professionals |Abortion is not restricted based on gestational age | State Medicaid funds cover abortion

Pre-Roe abortion ban is still in place and can be enforced if Roe is overturned |Abortion is banned at fetal viability, generally 24–26 weeks of pregnancy | Patients forced to make two trips—one for in-person counseling and another at least 24 hours later for the abortion | State Medicaid coverage of abortion care is banned except in very limited circumstances | Medication abortion must be provided in person because state bans the use of telehealth or mailing pills or requires in-person visit | Parental consent or notice is required for a minor's abortion | Only physicians can provide abortions and not other qualified health care professionals |Medication abortion is restricted through unnecessary regulations | Unnecessary regulations are in force and designed to shutter abortion clinics without basis in medical standards
